p.em: These exercises emphasize use of some important trigonometric identities. Review Appendix A of Anton (Handout). Here's a summary of summary important identities. Don't feel obligated to memorize the Addition Formulas.

answer.p:
Reciprocal identities will be helpful. Also, 1-\sin^2 \theta = \cos^2\theta, by the Pythagorean Identity.
\frac{\tan \theta \, \csc^3 \theta}{\cot^4 \theta \, \sin^5 \theta\, (1-\sin^2 \theta)} = \csc^3 \theta \sec^7 \theta

statement.p: Suppose \cos(\theta) = 0.3 and \theta is in Quadrant IV. Find the sine of the \theta using the Pythagorean Identity.
Starting with the identity \sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1, derive two similar identities involving tangent and cotangent, respectively.

hint.p:
Divide both sides by \cos^2\theta to see that
\tan^2 \theta + 1 = \sec^2 \theta
Divide both sides by \sin^2\theta to see that
1+\cot^2 \theta = \csc^2 \theta

statement.p:
Use the Addition Formulas and the Opposite Angle Identities to derive the Difference Formulas
\sin(\alpha - \beta) = \sin \alpha \cos \beta - \cos \alpha \sin \beta \quad \text{and} \quad \cos(\alpha-\beta) = \cos \alpha \cos \beta + \sin \alpha \sin \beta.

hint.p: Write the difference of angles as a sum \sin(\alpha - \beta) = \sin(\alpha +(-\beta)).

statement.p: Use the Difference Formulas above and the Special Triangles to find the exact values of \sin(15^\circ) and \cos(15^\circ).

hint.p: 15^\circ = 45^\circ - 30^\circ and the exact values of these can be found from the special triangles.

statement.p:
Use the Addition Formulas to derive the following Double Angle Identities
\sin (2\theta) = 2\sin\theta \cos\theta \quad \text{and} \quad \cos (2\theta) = \cos^2 \theta - \sin^2 \theta.

hint.p: Write the double angle as a sum \sin (2\theta) = \sin (\theta + \theta).

statement.p:
Use the Double Angle Identity for Cosine above to derive the Half-Angle Identities
\cos(x/2) = \pm \sqrt{\frac{1+\cos x}{2}} \quad \text{and} \quad \sin(x/2) = \pm \sqrt{\frac{1-\cos x}{2}}.

solution.p:
I'll do one. From the double angle identity:
\cos(2\theta) &= \cos^2 \theta - \sin^2 \theta
&= 1-\sin^2 \theta - \sin^2 \theta
\cos(2\theta)&= 1-2\sin^2 \theta
Solve this last equation for \sin^2 \theta,
\sin^2 \theta = \frac{1-\cos(2\theta)}{2}
Thus,
\sin \theta =\pm\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos(2\theta)}{2}},
where the sign is determined by the quadrant \theta is in. Let \theta = x/2, then 2\theta = x and
\sin (x/2) =\pm\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos(x)}{2}}.
